summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to defense counsel in the case of United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, providing notice of the government's intent to call a clinical expert witness at trial. The expert is expected to testify about the dynamics of sexual abuse, grooming, and trauma in minors. The letter also requests reciprocal discovery from the defense.

events.title: Government Expert Witness Notice
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office provides formal notice of its intent to call a clinical expert witness to testify about sexual abuse, grooming, and trauma dynamics in the trial of Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Initial Discovery Request
events.description: The Government had previously requested reciprocal discovery from the defense, which is reiterated in this letter.

locations: Silvio J. Mello Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
Cohen & Gresser LLP, 800 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10022
Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, P.C., 150 East Tenth Avenue, Denver, CO 80203
Law Offices of Bobbi C. Stemheim, 33 West 19th Street-4th Fl., New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The government plans to call a clinical expert witness to testify about how perpetrators target vulnerable individuals, use grooming and manipulation (rather than forcible rape) to abuse minors, and how trauma affects victim disclosure and memory.
The expert has not evaluated any specific victim in the Maxwell case, and the government does not intend for her to testify about specific victims; her testimony will be general about abuse dynamics.
The government is producing notes from its interviews with the expert witness and a list of her prior testimony.
The letter formally requests reciprocal discovery from the defense regarding any expert witnesses and evidence they intend to use at trial.
The document is a procedural filing in the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330), indicating the trial preparation phase.
